newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy ERM talks to begin after budget vote - Prodi.
newsitem.headline: Italy ERM talks to begin after budget vote - Prodi.

text.p: Prime Minister Romano Prodi said in an interview published on Tuesday that Italy would begin formal talks on bringing lira back into the European exchange rate mechanism (ERM) once his 1997 budget was approved by the lower house of parliament.

The budget package, which is designed to hack 62.5 trillion lire ($41 billion) off next year's deficit, has to be ratified by parliament before the end of the year. But ministers expect much of the voting to be completed by the end of November.
Prodi told the financial daily Il Sole 24 Ore that Italy was holding informal bilateral talks "to carry the lira into the ERM by December 31".

"There are no formal talks yet...we'll start these serious negotiations after the budget is approved by the Chamber of Deputies, which will give the government more contractual power," he told the newspaper.
The lira was pushed out of the ERM in a 1992 currency crisis and the exact timing of its return is likely to depend on how the government's 1997 austerity budget fares in parliament.
